No s. Me encanta. Es de los que ms disfruto de este disco. <br />Despus de Nothing fails, o ms bien, con ella inicia una serie de tres baladas en el disco, la cual puede parecer aburrida a algunos, pero no a aquellos que puedan extraer lo esencial de su sentir. Intermission, la segunda de ellas, no es especialmente emotiva hasta que llega al estribillo: &quot;And I know, that love will keep us together...&quot; , realmente hermoso y esperanzador. Perfecto para una de esas solitarias noches invernales.  La siguiente, X-tatic process, es un momento nostlgico con aire a trova, exclusivamente de guitarras acsticas y uno que otro arreglo pop. Este track es extremadamente delicioso, que va, es uno de esos momentos Nescaf.  Pero lo ms ms precioso del tema es cuando dice: &quot;I always wish that I could find, someone as beautiful as you, but in the process I forgot, that I was special too...&quot; Una bella muestra de una dulce renunciacin, pero sobre todo de una buena autoestima.  <br />Mother and father es otro de los ya soporficos recuerdos de Madonna acerca de su niez, ya lo hemos visto en Oh father, Promise to try, Mer girl, Inside of me y tantos tantos tems mas... En este caso su remembranza no es excesivamente brillante, pero el rap puede ser pegajoso en ocasiones. <br />Muchos opinaron que Die another day no debi haberse incluido en esta obra, pero yo no veo porque. Los arreglos &quot;hi-tech&quot; son realmente geniales, creo que encaja perfectamente en el ambiente electrnico del disco. Adems del video que es de los mejores de la carrera de Madonna. Un 10 para esa rola. <br />Por ltimo, no poda faltar un punto dbil, como en todos los discos producidos y por haber, y en este caso se llama &quot;Easy ride&quot;, rola nostlgica y con arreglos de cuerdas que seguro es un intento de evocar grandezas como &quot;Live to tell&quot; u &quot;Oh father&quot;, pero aqu se queda muy pero muy lejos, y que bueno que es el ltimo track, as le puedes apagar sin tener que adelantar.  <br />En resumen, muy bien por Maddy que nos demuestra que a sus 45 aos an tiene mucho que aportar a la obra comn, aunque el xito comercial no sea el mismo que el de sus mejores tiemposy ahora tenga que valerse de las estrellas actuales como Britney para hacerse notar. Vale.

B00005JMFR|3.0|One thing that sticks out from \\"Reloaded\\" is the Oracle telling Neo \\"You have to make up your own mind\\". That's really how I feel about \\"Matrix Revolutions\\". I really was disappointed with Matrix Revolutions, but that doesn't make it bad. It's just one of those things where you can't count on professional reviews, nor can you rely on our reviews. It's the type of movie you'll either love or hate, and it's up to you, the person reading this, to decide for yourself.<br />Everybody who likes this movie has their own reasons for liking it, and everyone who hates it has their reasons too; most are good reasons. Speaking for myself, I bet that I will like this movie a lot more on DVD. That was the way it was for Reloaded. I was disappointed in the theater, but quite satisfied by it at home and had much more fun with it. Don't ask why. <br />As for Revolutions, for me, it provided no real answers to the questions that Reloaded created. Call me silly, but at the end of Reloaded I thought that they were actually in a matrix within a matrix. They weren't really \\"free\\", they were plugged into a `special' matrix for people who begin to resist the `real' matrix, so they think they are fighting this war, only it's just another matrix, and the machines are going to wipe out Zion, basically emptying their recycle bin and start over, and they've done it five times already. That was the impression that \\"The Architect\\" gave me in Reloaded, and after Smith hopped into a human body, and Neo is using the force to stop sentinels it wasn't a far stretch to assume they were all still \\"plugged in\\" even though they thought they weren't. Where Neo's power comes from is a total mystery to me now.<br />A lot of the people who are confused by this finally, have been slammed by Pro-Revolutions reviewers here for being closed-minded. For me, confused is more the word to use, and good movies aren't supposed to confuse people. I mean if you want to provoke thought, that's one thing. But the only thought Revolutions provoked in me was how long and confusing the whole thing was. <br />There are computer dorks here too who simply think anyone who didn't \\"get it\\" was stupid. But that's the internet for you, isn't it? Then there are those who remind us that Reloaded and Revolutions are both the final chapter, and we're supposed to factor that in, and put the two movies together in our minds, and THEN it will make more sense. I watched Reloaded at home, about a30 minutes before leaving to see Revolutions, and it was no help at all. <br />I would like to see Revolutions again, so maybe I'll get what all the 5-star reviewers here got that I didn't. I tried so hard to like it; except the movie is so slow (The big battle was so big and long that after a time even that got boring). I don't think I can sit through it in a theater again, so I'll wait for the DVD, and remain optimistic that this will be a better movie for me at home than in the theaters. I bet that may be the case for a lot of us.<br />This review is probably no help to anyone. I really, really love the matrix concept. I think the first matrix was as far as they should have gone. THAT was thought provoking. \\"Revolutions\\" was fun. The effects were the best I've seen, but it's mired down by this convoluted plot that I can't figure out. Once again this does not make Matrix Revolutions a bad movie or unworthy of your time. That is for you, and you alone to decide for yourself.

B00002SSRZ|5.0|This isn't a review of Abraxas, if you need to see one of those, there are plenty of those around.  BTW, I think Abraxas on it's own is is four and one-half stars.<br />This is a review of the of Abraxas in DTS.  Sound is something that has always intrigued me.  In the early 1970's, stereo companies were experimenting with quadraphonic sound, with Columbia Records producing more than anyone else.  While the quad records had some walkover of sounds from one speaker to the other, the quad tapes had their sounds wonderfully separated.<br />Abraxas, with the chimes, swirls of sounds, and organs resonating at full-force was one of the best of the quad records.<br />When I saw Abraxas on DTS with 5:1 sound, I jumped at the opportunity to own it.  I have a 5:1 DTS Yamaha Stereo Receiver (5280) at home, but it is in my car (Acura TL with the ELS 5:1 DTS CD/DVD Player) that this CD really shines.  Whereas the sounds were somewhat separate on the record, they are distinctly separate on the DTS system: so crisp and so clear that you can close your eyes and envision yourself sitting in the midst of Santana playing around you.<br />If you truly enjoy the sound of music taken to the &quot;next level,&quot; get yourself a DTS system, and make Abraxas your first DTS CD.  You will not be disappointed.

B0000CDLA7|1.0|First of all, allow me to make myself clear: I'm not especially a DT fan, but I'm not dead-set against them, either (heck, I own all their CD's to date). I'm not going to add to the debate whether this is a DT album or not as, frankly, I don't much care. As long as it's good music, prog, straight rock, AOR, heavy metal, even classical, I'm all for it.<br />There lies the problem, though, because this album is a musical void.<br />And they're supposed to have done this in three weeks? Come on. What did they do on the last twenty days? This sounds more like an afternoon effort. Definitely a millionnaire CD, though. I mean, a new band committing this (yes, as in \\"commit a crime\\") wouldn't even find a label.<br />I already felt that DT weren't comfortable with metal, as The Glass Prison is in my opinion a dreadful song. Now, they've tried it on a whole album, which may have been a good choice as they hadn't really explored the genre yet. Problem is, they haven't got a clue.<br />Oh, sure, the album as a whole *sounds* heavy, but it's just noise, not music, I'm afraid. There's no feeling, no nothing. Just the \\"wall of sound\\" approach, as if to cover the fact that they're dead creatively speaking. Okay, so they're playing faster than they ever did before, so what? Bad news, guys, there are tons of guys out there who are playing faster than you do. And also better, thank God.<br />But then, what can you expect from a band which lost its collective soul on '94? Because, let's face it, what makes the big difference between prog and other kinds of rock is the keyboard. All the great prog groups, past and present, have been keyboard-fronted. DT was, too, until their best songwriter left. Rudess just doesn't make any impression. Maybe because the others don't let him, I don't know, but to me, he sounds like a session player added to the band as an afterthought. Don't get me wrong; there is a lot of keyboard here, but nothing special. Exception to the rule here is \\"Endless Sacrifice\\", where he lifts the song up some. But at 11 minutes plus, it's still three times too long compared with the ideas contained within.<br />Myung is there but does nothing special either, which is a shame (I edited that, as my earlier review was decidedly unfair to the guy--sorry, John). Portnoy is okay but unimaginative, and far from the drum-God lots of fans portray him as (in fact, there are quite a number of more accomplished stick-men out there). LaBrie's voice just isn't fit for metal and, as said before, Petrucci only plays faster than on earlier albums, definitely not better.<br />Also, these guys seem to have the impression that you have to write looooong songs to be labeled prog. Truth is, bands such as Marillion (Fish-era), Genesis (PG-era) or Arena, to name but a few, wrote quite a few excellent prog songs which were very short. On the other hand, Santa Esmeralda would never get called a prog group, but they have a few long songs to their repertoire (and, musically speaking, \\"Don't Let Me Be Misunderstood\\" is a much more creative song than DT has written in ages, IMHO). So, in my opinion, the length of the song has never been a factor, otherwise Mike Oldfield would be the king of prog (heck, \\"Amarok\\" is a single piece, an hour long), and he most definitely is not.<br />Bottom line: if you want heavy metal, listen to Maiden's \\"Dance of Death\\" of WASP' \\"The Crimson Idol\\", which is in my mind the best heavy metal release ever. If you think TOT is good, just listen to it and weep. But then, it was done in close to three *years*, and it shows. No fillers, there, just great songs from cover to cover. If you want prog, go buy \\"Legacy\\" or wait for Shadow Gallery's next release. And if you want something cross-genre, grab a copy of \\"Avantasia\\" or, better still, Nightwish's \\"Century Child\\".<br />Next time, guys, try to remember that, if less is more, in this case, more (ie speed) is definitely less (quality). And another thing: the best musicians are not thosewho play the fastest, but those who play together. Otherwise, it's no use being part of a band.<br />Oh, by the way--I must admit that you surprised me, as I was quite sure you couldn't go any lower than \\"6\\". Shows how much I know, heh? But you know the worst of it? There *is* tremendous potential, here. So next time, please take the time to do a proper album, as a few jam sessions just aren't enough, even if your devoted fans keep telling you that even God isn't fit to play with you (\\"One and a half month to write songs is beyond stupid, it's insane.\\" -- Tom Englund, Evergrey -- guess what he would think about three weeks?)<br />Talking about the fans, the hateful attitude of some is, I feel, the most embarrassing, here. Just because someone doesn't like TOT makes him/her a moron? Come on, guys, show a few brain cells from time to time. If I name a CD that I like and you don't, does that make you morons, too? Of course not. You love TOT? Good for you. I respect that, although I don't personally. So please respect the fact than other people may have different tastes (and, no, I'm not pining for I&W 2). Thank you.<br />And even if you think this is a scorcher, just thought what they could have accomplished had they taken the time to work properly at this. Every way you look at it, making an album in three weeks is a bad thing... and admitting it is stupid. Because the guys who like it may be disappointed that you didn't take the time to polish it and those who don't won't like being taken for fools.<br />Worst of it is, I really wanted to love this album after being disappointed in 6. Oh well, maybe next time...

B000000645|4.0|La idea de un do folk sicdelico slo pudo haber sido concebida (y exitosa) en la experimental segunda mitad de los 60. La propuesta de Heron y Williamson parece haber sido: &quot;hagamos las canciones ms extraas posibles, agregemos la mayor cantidad de instrumentos posibles, con letras lo ms bizarras posibles y veamos que pasa&quot;. An para los estndares de la sicodelia de la poca ste es un disco difcil de digerir, sin toques comerciales, donde las melodas se desdibujan rpidamente en medio de un bormardeo de instrumentos exticos y voces montonas. Definitivamente excesivo pero al mismo tiempo una experiencia fascinante para quienes quieren ir un poco ms all de los tipicos ejercicios pop sicodlicos ingleses o las interminables improvisaciones del otro lado del Atlntico. Dentro del alocado ambiente del disco los mejores pasajes se consiguen cuando el do (acompaado por algunos amigos) aplica mayor densidad instrumental y vocal, como ocurre en Waltz Of The New Moon con un notable uso del clavecn o en Three Is A Green Crown, un hipntico tema de casi 8 minutos que parece transportarte a la misma India, dejando a Beatles, Stones y muchos otros mal parados en este tipo de experimentos. No todo funciona en los 49 minutos, hay temas como A Very Celular Song que consiguen su objetivo de crear atmsferas pero se requiere ms que eso. Nightfall parece cerrar el disco con una nota melanclica dentro del caos generalizado, una buena despedida despes de un alucingeno viaje al lado ms extravagante de la sicodelia.
B000002KFJ|4.0|Many people out there would have you believe Sabotage is a terrible album, which is a perspective I find vexing, as it is a very strong and ambitious outing by Black Sabbath. <br />Nearly every song here is a strength, but there's 3 bonafide Sabbath classics, those being the high-energy opener Hole in the Sky, the album centrepiece Symptom of the Universe, and the self-absorbed bleakness of Megalomania. Thrill of it All is Sabbath rockin' like they should be, the Writ is another Multi-part epic. The rest of the tracks in the album are examples of when Sabbath's skills begin to falter. Don't Start (Too Late) is a really short acoustic guitar track, but the reason this album doesn't get the full 5 stars is because of the oddity that is Supertzar and Am I Going Insane [Radio Edit], which, although not bad tracks, just don't sound like sabbath. <br />Overall and on its own, this album is a true Sabbath classic, and although they certainly had better albums, it'll please fans of Sabbath, Ozzy, and tr00 Metal a great deal.

0553275976|5.0|On the surface, the book is a satire of the puffed up 80s.  The &quot;Vanities&quot; that are being blown up are all the pretensions that people put around themselves.  Sherman McCoy is a man who would've exuded strength and power in a prior age.  But is he a &quot;Master of the Universe&quot; bond trader (a term coined by Tom Wolfe, later to make it into the popular lexicon) or just another fluffed up product of society?  Indeed, the book explores this question.  You'll be surprised by the answer!<br />Is it just a novel of the 80s?  I disagree, for several reasons...<BR>- The greed of the 80s reappeared in the past 5 years.<BR>- If you look hard enough, one of the characters in the book is running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004.<BR>- The deep characters Wolfe creates ring true today.<BR>- New York again sees itself in a time of great change.  Maybe there are lessons in this literature?<br />Is it the Great American Novel?  Who knows...  But it can be read with &quot;A Man in Full&quot; to understand grit, determination and what does make America different.
B00004TH7Z|1.0|Brave New World: the upsetting first release of 21st century Maiden which follows the same pattern, track after track, and simply does not rip. Most songs on this release are extremely \\"let's sit around in this studio for and hour or two and see what we come up with\\" sort of songs. B0000DJZA5|3.0|The release of this album could have been a great chance to hear the songs on the original without all of the extra stuff that Phil Spector added to it in 1970. Unfortunately, with no real involvement from the surviving Beatles, Let It Be...Naked is nothing more than a revisionist's version of what Let It Be might have sounded like had it been recorded in the present day.<br />While this new version is sonically very good, all of the atmosphere of the original has been lost. All snippets of Beatle chatter have been excised, for one thing, resulting in a couple of very awkward fade-outs. And practically all evidence of what used to be referred to as &quot;echo&quot; have been excised as well, resulting in a very dull-sounding (albeit crystal clear) mix.<br />For most people, the chance to hear &quot;The long and winding road&quot; without all the schlocky strings was probably the biggest motivator behind the purchase of this album. Unfortunately, a different take was used, and it isn't a better take. Moreover, McCartney's piano is too intrusive. (The version on Wings Over America is better...)<br />On &quot;I've got a feeling&quot;, Lennon and McCartney's voices are mixed to the center, rather than to opposite channels, diminishing the effect of the counterpoint later in the song.<br />And, I'm sorry, but Phil Spector's production of &quot;Across the universe&quot; is miles better than the one on offer here. Without the backing vocals, the recording sounds pretty much like the throwaway track it originally was.<br />The bonus disc is a well-intentioned effort to make up for some of the lost atmosphere of the original, but it is ultimately an unsuccessful one. Something closer to the Get Back album that was originally intended would have been better...

B0000AMRJC|5.0|The classic to end all classics:  Brian De Palma's 1983 remake of the 1932 Howard Hawks classic &quot;Scarface&quot;.  This movie is loud, brash, over-the-top, relentlessly macho, and filled to the brim with testosterone--and no fewer than 206 F-words--courtesy of De Palma's direction, Oliver Stone's screenplay and Al Pacino's ferocious performance as the exiled Cuban yayo dealer Tony Montana.<br />The &quot;Scarface&quot; story is well known:  the rags-to-riches, exhilirating highs and mind-numbing lows of Tony Montana--a Cuban criminal who is exiled along with 25,000 others by Fidel Castro in 1980.  Tony begins as yet another poverty-stricken refugee in a Miami camp (albeit an extraordinarily ambitious one).  Soon, though, through a little luck and plenty of sheer ruthlessness he rises astronomically to the top of slimy, bloody Miami cocaine heap in a very short time with the help of his loyal, but none-too-bright friend Manny (Stephen Bauer) and woos the girlfriend (Michelle Pfeiffer) of his &quot;soft&quot; coke-dealing boss (Robert Loggia).  However, his ruthlessness and inability to trust anyone--which helped him rise to the top--threaten to become his downfall in the end.<br />So, what are this movie's strengths?  The direction, the eminently quotable screenplay (which has inspired countless rappers and stand-up comedians to this day), and Al Pacino's over-the-top performance quipped with a hilarious attempt at a Cuban accent.  There's good reason this film became the cult classic that it is today.<br />What are the weaknesses?  Well, it's THREE HOURS LONG, for one.  &quot;Scarface&quot; definitely starts to lose steam during its last hour.  Secondly, the music is UNBELIEVEABLY cheesy.  The music (and the fashion too) is aggressively, in-your-face 1983.  No doubt about it.  It's like the composer was aspiring to imitate Frank Stallone, rather than Nino Rota (composer of &quot;The Godfather&quot;).  <br />The DVD extras are great, detailing the film's making,its initial reception, and its enormous influence on hip-hop.  Noteworthy are the numerous interviews of rappers professing their love of the film, an interview with Oliver Stone who candidly explains how his addiction to cocaine forced him to move to France(!), plus the hilarious censorship placed on this notoriously profanity-laden film when it first got shown on network television (please see the above title).  <br />Twenty years later, &quot;Scarface&quot; has taken its rightful place along the great American gangster films of all time.  It may not be as good as &quot;The Godfather&quot;, but it's certainly more fun!

0345457684|5.0|Takeshi Kovacs, a native of Harlan's World and an ex-member of the thoroughly lethal UN Envoys, has inhabited many bodies in his career, both male and female, both natural and enhanced or even synthetic. That's the way life is lived in the 25th century. This ability to transfer personality and memories from one &quot;sleeve&quot; to another on demand also means it's seldom necessary to experience Real Death -- if you can afford it. It also means that the need for societal punishment usually results in having your cortical stack put on ice for a few decades, or even centuries -- and you might not get your own body back when you're released. Kovacs, though, is not typical, not even for an Envoy, and when he (or his consciousness) is needlecast across 180 light years to Earth by the excessively wealthy Laurens Bancroft to be offered a job investigating Bancroft's murder, he finds he can't refuse. The investigation gets him involved with all levels of Earth's society and with a wide variety of very artfully drawn characters, and he soon finds himself caught up in a vast conspiracy that he has very little chance of surviving. Woven through the story is Quellist philosophy (&quot;Take it personally&quot;) and Kovacs's previous history and the ghosts that haunt him. This blend of noir detective thriller and uncommonly inventive cyberpunk is an astonishing piece of work for a first novel, and I expect Morgan to become well known in the sf community in a very short space of time.

B0000CABBW|4.0|&quot;Whale Rider&quot; is a wonderful film about a young girl, Paikea, named for, according to the legend of her Maori people, rode a whale to New Zealand, and is the father of all Maoris. Paikea was meant to have a twin brother, who would have been the firstborn boy in the family, but he, along with Pai's mother, died seconds after he was born. Pai's father leaves the hospital, and his family, leaving her sympathetic grandmother, and her disappointed grandfather, the current chief of the tribe, to take care of her.<br />As Pai grows older, she becomes more and more interested in her roots, and believes that she is destined to become a leader. This becomes even more apparent to her when a visit from her father reveals that he is starting a new life and a new family in Germany. However Pai's grandfather, Koro, has very different plans in mind. Girls are not allowed to become Maori leaders. So he begins training young local boys to be cheifs, bringing an end to his family's reign as cheifs. But Pai continues to try and prove herself, ending with an amazing sequence that leaves you with the question &quot;How on earth did they do that?&quot;<br />Despite the plot, &quot;Whale Rider&quot; is not necessarily a girl power film. Nor is it just a coming-of-age film. It is a story about the conflict between old traditions and modern development, and finding a compromise in which the two can meet. The score is really haunting and beautiful, and the filmmaking is seamless. Even the story is well developed, and very believable. And, if you really want to know the answer to the question &quot;how on earth did they do that?&quot; there is a wonderful behind the scenes segment on the DVD that will surely answer all the questions you can pose, and more. This is absolutely a film that cannot be missed. It warms the cockles of your heart, and will leave you cheering your lungs out for its gutsy, spunky heroine.
B000069HJM|1.0|The first 7 tracks of this album are shockingly bad.  This is another case of a progressive rock band from the seventies trying to change its image to match the sound of the times.  Almost all progressive rock bands did it and almost all failed miserably.  <br />On this album, Supertramp tries to incorporate the disco, dance club sound of the mid eighties.  This is not the original disco sound of the late seventies/early eighties (Bee Gees, Donna Summer, etc.)  This is what the disco dance club evolved to, after mixing in punk, new wave and electronica.  All the songs are short, 4 minute pop tunes.  Some of the lyrics are embarrassingly bad pop, love song lyrics.<br />Some of the music reminds me of Grace Jones' dicso sound.  Other parts have that pop saxophone sound that was popular with the female led groups, such as Quarterflash.  In some places, they sound like Frankie Goes to Hollywood.  None of it is the Supertramp sound.  I always applaud groups for experimenting, trying something new or expanding the music. But, in this case, Supertramp is just copying others.<br />All isn't completely lost.  The last 2 tracks are pretty good and go back to the old Supertramp sound.  The last track, An Awful Thing To Waste, sounds like an updated improvement on the song Cannonball, from the previous album, Brother Where Are You Bound?<br />In 1984, Roger Hodgson left Supertramp.  He and Rick Davies were the composers and singers.  They needed each other.  Neither has the voice to carry an album by themselves.  They were very effective in trading off vocals.  They also needed each other to keep the song compositions in line.<br />In 1984, Hodgson released Eye of the Storm and Supertramp released Brother Where Are You Bound?  Both were fairly good albums, keeping with the Supertramp sound.  In 1987, Supertramp released this (Free As a Bird) and Hodgson released Hai Hai.  They were both collections of short songs trying to capatilize on the sounds of the times.  Both failed miserably and led to the disappearance of Hodgson and Supertramp for over 10 years.

0375703861|4.0|White teeth is an excellent novel, mixing humor with a variety of underlying issues in society today.  In many ways it reminds me of works by Nick Hornby, but achieving significantly more depth. <br />I lived in London for several years and found the fears of both immigrant and native residents refreshingly realistic in the way they are portrayed in the book.  A cultural melting pot is often held up as the achievement of the modern age, where we trancend national and cultural boundaries.  But as Smith illustrates so well, it is not the intellectual escaping to the leafy suburbs who have to deal with the issues of living the ideal, but real people like Archie and Samad.<br />The book explores a great deal of heavy subject matter, but does so in a cloak of comic prose, which makes it no only palatable but hugely enjoyable.  <br />One reviewer gives this novel one star based on factual inaccuracies about India and Jamaica, he may well be right.  However I think he misses the point, this is a book about people and relationships not places.  The issues dealt with are very real for millions of people and the book is factual in it's account of how ordinary people struggle to deal with them as they go about their lives.<br />White Teeth has had a great deal of publicity and hype since it's publication.  Often this predjudices me against books or movies, but in this case I agree with the hype and can only recommend you read it.

0393057658|5.0|This is a very readable, witty book, which on the surface is about baseball, and the application of statistical analysis (sabremetrics) to the evaluating of players and strategies (knowledge of statistics is not necessary; he doesn't get into that:  it's all about people and ideas).  A basic knowledge of baseball is certainly useful, as Lewis drops the names of many players and mentions certain types of plays (i.e., hit and run, sacrifice bunt, etc.) without pausing to explain them, but also probably not essential.  The people, and the lively writing of Lewis, are at the center here.<br />Lewis nicely weaves together the personal stories of the A's general manager (GM), Billy Beane, other team execs and scouts, and the individual players who were often considered misfits by other teams for a very particular reason (a year or two too old, an odd pitching motion, etc.), but were considered bargains by the As.  He gives good detail for anyone who has ever wondered how teams decide who to draft, or how a general manager negotiates player deals with other GMs (and, like Red Auerbach was for the Celtics in the 60s, is so good at picking the pockets of other teams that after a while they are reticent to deal with him).  And it's very interesting how Beane, a promising high school player who could be a poster child for the failure of the old, scout-driven school, takes it upon himself to dismantle that establishment with sabremetrics.<br />At a deeper level, the book is about several other matters:<BR>- how does any organization evaluate and hire people?<BR>- how does a radically new way of approaching a business develop?<BR>- what -- and how long -- does it take for the new method to displace the previous way of doing things, and -- more importantly -- the people who do it that way?<br />In the case of baseball, the development of sabremetrics -- which developed the new strategic insights based on detailed analyses of baseball's mother lode of stats -- has been ongoing forabout 30 years.  And the success of the Oakland As -- consistently making the playoffs with a payroll one-third of the Yankees -- is its first major test, and victory.  (A few other teams, like the Red Sox, recently say they are heavily influenced by it, although paying huge dollars for 37-year-old veterans like Curt Schilling may not be the best proof.)  But at most clubs the old-timers who run the game still prefer to rely on their subjective judgments.<br />In other fields, such as high tech, the head-in-the-sand approach taken by most baseball people would lead to the death of the company.  And perhaps that is why some companies do die.  Certainly plenty of studies have shown that most companies make hiring decisions in ways that -- like most baseball teams -- are highly subjective.  And what other industry has the historical, objective stats on performance that baseball has to develop the strategies from?  Other than, perhaps, investment banking and direct marketing, maybe none.  So, few could duplicate the depth of analysis, but many could profit from the style of thinking involved.<br />In any case, a very enjoyable read -- I read it in a couple days over Thanksgiving -- and highly recommended.

I just picked up OK Computer this June, and it quickly became my favourite album, and I bought Amnesiac, The Bends, and Hail to the Thief during the course of the summer (and Kid A in September or October).<br />Amnesiac and The Bends, which I purchased simultaneously, took only about a week to grow on me (Amnesiac, predictably, took longer.) But after a bit I loved them both and said-- I have to buy the new one. I did, and through 5 songs or so, it proved quite disappointing. (&quot;They were always delightfully weird, now they're just weird.&quot;) I gave it a chance though, and it came around-- WAY around.<br />To people who have been saying that HTTT has been getting such praise just because it's Radiohead and Radiohead can't do any wrong, I will point out that this is my 2nd favourite Radiohead album, even better than The Bends and Kid A, though nothing tops OK Computer.<br />This album, which blends the sounds of Kid A/Amnesiac and The Bends quite nicely, is a good step back on track-- (IMO with all the great songs on Kid A and Amnesiac -- and I loved the avant-garde-ness -- there were too many not-so-good songs [e.g. You And Whose Army, both Morning Bell's, Kid A, Dollars and Cents] to qualify them as masterpieces.)<br />One thing I've noticed about HTTT is that while past Radiohead records have stuck to one theme or sound, this one tries to cover everything-- amazingly the plan works-- and as a result, sounds more like a collection of songs than a concept album.<br />And cover everything, they do-- the piano ballads (Sail to the Moon), techno oddities (Backdrifts, The Gloaming), piano-ballads morphed into techno oddities (Sit Down. Stand Up.), dirgy funeral moaning (We suck Young Blood), old-style guitar-bass-drums (There There, Go to Sleep, Scatterbrain), sublime acoustic ditties (I Will), piano-and-bass-funk (A Punchup at a Wedding), and just-plain-unclassifiable stuff (the spooky and sortof rocking Where I End and You Begin, the zany 3-songs-in-one 2+2=5, the manic synth-bass number Myxomatosis, and the amazing closer A Wolf at the Door, on which Yorke does something that resembles rapping-- yea you heard it.)<br />You will find little &quot;to hell with the music and lyrics&quot; crap that hurt the last 2 albums; here, with only a few exceptions, every song is innovative, unique, meaningful, and incredible. And the songs that aren't so great.. are still pretty good. And there's 14 songs so you'll find plenty of genius :)<br />HTTT contains 4 of what I consider the best songs ever, period, in Sit Down. Stand Up. (my all-time favourite), We suck Young Blood, Myxomatosis, and A Wolf at the Door.<BR>here I'll rate the songs for the heck of it:<BR>2+2=5 9/10<BR>Sit Down. Stand Up. 10/10<BR>Sail to the Moon 9/10<BR>Backdrifts 7.5/10<BR>Go to Sleep 8/10<BR>Where I End and You Begin 9/10<BR>We suck Young Blood 9.5/10<BR>The Gloaming 6/10<BR>There There 8.5/10<BR>I Will 8.5/10<BR>A Punch-up at a Wedding 9/10<br />Myxomatosis 9/10<BR>Scatterbrain 8.5/10<BR>A Wolf at the Door 9.5/10<br />As for who I'd recommend this album to-- if you're a casual fan, definitely go for it (if you're a huge fan, you probably already have it.) If you've heard There There or Go to Sleep on the radio, beware-- these 2 songs are probably the most traditional on the album, so if you can keep an open mind and appreciate a little bit of different music, I'd still say go for it. If you're new to Radiohead-- don't start here. Start at OK Computer :)

B000002U82|5.0|The negative reviews on here (or at least the two most vitriolic ones) talk about how the songs on DSOTM are fodder for guitar solos, and how they have nothing &quot;special&quot; to distinguish between them.<br />I have to ask, are we listening to the same album? Because... there are only three guitar solos in Dark Side of the Moon.  Out of nine songs.  Not to mention the fact that the songs that do have guitar solos are not centered around those solos.  &quot;Time&quot;, &quot;Money&quot;, and &quot;Any Colour You Like&quot;, the three tunes WITH guitar solos, either have another instrumental solo accompanying the guitar, or lengthy intros and sound effect pastiches that balance it out.  The solo from &quot;Time&quot; for instance, illustrates a person's whole lifetime! It's a soundtrack to growing up, and the solo brings the drama!<br />Also, if you can't see what makes every track &quot;special&quot; and you think it's &quot;repetitive&quot;, I have to really wonder about your IQ.  Every track has funny little nuances, complex little things that make every single track worth relishing.  The whole album is not built around &quot;Time&quot;.  If anything, I would say the climax is &quot;Us and Them&quot;.  But that's not even the case; every song has a specific message and soundscape, and the variety is so endless one wonders how a group of 5 people (including Parsons) could have done something like this.  It is truly almost extraterrestrial in its majesty.<br />This is the greatest piece of music ever written, period, the end, and it will continue to resonate with everyone until the end of time.  Some people love to hate it, because some people are like that, but they know in their heart of hearts that they love it.  So buy it, buy this 93 Anniversary edition, and buy it now.  Listen to it anywhere; it's perfect for every situation from making out in the car to hanging out with your friends to listening alone in a darkened room.  Listen with an open mind, and don't hate it just to rebel.  Everyone has the right to enjoy this wonderful album, and we should all thank Roger, Dave, Rick, and Nick for imparting us with this piece of humanity, theirs and ours.<br />PS: Radiohead wouldn't know their asses from a hole in the wall if it wasn't for Pink Floyd.

0156027321|4.0|&quot;Life of Pi&quot; brings together a swirl of beautiful turns-of-phrase with an eccentric tale about a 16 year-old Indian boy lost at sea for 7 months.  With him on the lifeboat: sparse water, a make-shift raft, and a 450 pound bengal tiger.  Pi, the main character, must tame the lion well enough to survive the sea.<br />Martel's writing style is at once whimsical and profound.  He claims that he has found a story that will make you believe in God (Pi is a Christian/Hindu/Muslim).  But the beauty is not the punchline, it's the process.  Martel sees &quot;riots of flowers,&quot; teachers who &quot;came into my dark head and lit a match,&quot; and neckies that are nooses, &quot;inverted though it is, it will hang a man nonetheless.&quot; Often you will stop the story to muse over the words.<br />The only downpoint of the book is that after about 100 pages of beautiful writing, it falls away for the real story of the lifeboat.  Interesting though it is, you will probably find yourself longing for the established style and wondering where it went.  Fortunately, the story will then carry you through to the end--a hilarious and profound explanation of the boat wreck to a couple of insurance agents.  Definitely worth reading.
B000002P2V|5.0|Although its original birth came from Pete Townshend's scrapped attempt to resurrect his ill-fated \\"Lifehouse\\" project, \\"Who Are You\\" pronounces the death of the entire idea of growing older with grace. Though the Who were still young when the album was released in 1978, the paranoid fear of a heyday coming to an end was intensified by the rapidly growing punk and disco movements, both of which were making it hard for bands like the Who to find their feet again. And the exhilirating material within \\"Who Are You\\" perfectly articulates the band's scorn and contempt.<br />From the clever cynical opener 'New Song,' Pete Townshend bashes the facelessness of pop music, as Roger Daltrey's throaty roar sarcastically describes the elements of \\"radio standards.\\" John Entwistle's rage filled 'Had Enough' is anthem-like, and his sci-fi tinged '905' unintentionally expresses creative frustration in the line \\"Every sentence in my head, someone else has said.\\" (The song was actually part of a bloated concept album idea the bassist had, but never used.) The angry but shapely in form 'Sister Disco' fits perfectly, while 'Music Must Change' and 'Guitar And Pen' express a feeling of lost youthful musical innocence and dreams. The suicidal 'Love Is Coming Down' is an interesting addition to Townshend's credits, but it is the ominous six-minute title track that captures the mood of the album best. It contains one of Daltrey's most fiery vocal performances, and the band's well-established love of studio technology. The song was written by Townshend after a real-life bad escapade after a night of drinking and less-than-casually meeting two members of the Sex Pistols.<br />Their last album with legendary drummer Keith Moon, who died after the album's release, \\"Who Are You\\" is one of the group's most angst-filled moments, remarkable because it was hatched at a time when all the angst was coming from the play-dirty punk bands that were rising to ever-increasing notoriety. It is the anthem of derision and rightfully bitter feelings of a band that found themselves out of place.ision and rightfully bitter feelings of a band that found themselves out of place.

THE VOICE IS PERFECT, ARRANGEMENTS ARE WONDERFUL AND IT REALLY COMES FROM THE HEART OF A TRUE ARTIST.WHITNEY IS AMAZING..... NOBODY CAN DO BETTER.......... SO EMOTIONAL, POWERFUL. &quot; O HOLY NIGHT&quot; IS SO BOMBASTIC........ ALL THOSE DIVAS TRYING TO DO IT BEFORE COULDNT DO IS AS POWERFUL AS WHITNEY DID........<BR>SO, TO YOU, CRANKY REVIWER. 6305280762|4.0|Flush with the success of The Poseidon Adventure, Irwin Allen found his next disaster spectacle in this joint venture between two major movie studios.  Combining two projects into one, The Towering Inferno (a dual adaptation of the skyscraper fire thrillers The Tower and The Glass Inferno) is the disaster movie as epic adventure.  Featuring an all star cast, terrific special effects, and harrowing stunt work, the movie was a solid follow up to Allen's previous hit and it remains one the very best disaster movies of the seventies.  Highly recommended.

Enough said.<br />3. \\"Sk8er Boi\\"- A [single]<BR>A cute song. It's rock/pop song about a girl and boy that secretly both liked each other but the girl would never tell. It's also got a lesson to it. At the End, Avril sings about having a relationship with that boy.<br />4. \\"I'm With You\\"- B+ [single]<BR>This is a nice, winter-y song, that would be beautiful if Avril worked on it just a little more. It's got a nice violin when it's played, but towards the end Avril sounds like she's getting out of tune or possibly shouting.<br />5. \\"Mobile\\"- A<BR>Awesome song, awesome guitars. It's about moving away and leaving everything behind, and about changing. A song almost everybody can relate to if they ever moved before.<br />6. \\"Unwanted\\"- B<BR>Good the first few times, but definitely not her best. Like \\"Losing Grip\\" its kind of about betrayal, but its guitars are much harder, and the lyrics are not her best, and are a little on the strange side. <br />7. \\"Tomorrow\\"- B+<BR>Not the best song either, unless you're in a bad mood, because this song is just slow. Just like \\"Mobile,\\" it's about changing (sorta) and carries the \\"I'm not ready\\" message. The only instrument really played is the guitar in this song.<br />8. \\"Anything But Ordinary\\"- A+<BR>A very nice song, that's about being weird (and maybe just not fitting in). The lyrics are a little strange, but the song overall is very cute. It's kind of like Michelle Branch's \\"You Get Me.\\" One of my favorites on the CD. <BR> <BR>9. \\"Things I'll Never Say\\"- A+<BR>Cute song, with nice guitars in the beginning. Sure, it's a little juvenile, but I admire her way of writing this one. Anybody who has a crush can relate to this one!    <BR>  <BR>10. \\"My World\\"- B<BR>This song is about Avril and her growing up, but I really think she doesn't need this song tacked onto this CD. Not the best song on the CD, it doesn't reflect her talent.<br />11. \\"Nobody's Fool (If)\\"- A+<BR>This is a fun, half rap, half pop/rock song. Nice guitars in the beginning, and Avril does a good job with the rapping. I usually hate rap, but when Avril does it, it's good! It's about somebody trying to turn her into somebody else. You need to \\"step up\\" and sing this one!<br />12. \\"Too Much To Ask\\"- B-<BR>Not the best song on the CD, either. It's probably the worst song on the CD. The lyrics aren't the best, either... it could use some work, and her voice isn't her best. It's another song that's about not being true to yourself.    <br />13. \\"Naked\\"- A<BR>This is one of Avril's more romance-like songs. It's about ... yeah, you know. :P It's kind of pop, though- but it is a song about a deep relationship!   <BR>               <BR>OVERALL GRADE: 94/100 --A<br />Enjoy! And remember to check for Avril Lavigne's 2nd album (she promises it will be more `rock-ish'), coming late this year or early 2004! ;)

0790733226|2.0|I like Jodie Foster.  She's a terrific actress if given the right script (Silence of the Lambs springs to mind).  But, like any other human being, she isn't perfect.  Contact, apparently her creative child, ought to pop whatever &quot;genius balloon&quot; the folks in Hollywood have tried to pin on her sleeve. Added for good measure are some sophmoric attempts to engage in philosophizing about &quot;big&quot; issues (which end up being just plain dumb) and an ending that simply isn't worth the wait.  The long, long wait as Contact crawls to its anti-climactic conclusion.

B0000DJZA5|5.0|Considering what is passed off as music these days. . . . Beleive me, this is a welcomed breath of fresh air.    [...]The music in \\"Let it Be. . . Naked\\" has been available to Beatles fans through bootleg recordings for many years. The sound quality in a few of these bootleg editions is quite good. But, in others. . . well, you know. . . . \\"caveat emptor,\\" especially when it comes to underground music recordings.   This recording, however, gives the listener a fresh perspective on the \\"Get Back\\" sessions. For openers, the tapes have been remastered and cleaned, providing excellent sound quality. Although Beatles fans are familiar with the songs on this CD, the warmth and freshness of an \\"un-spector-ized\\" recording session is felt throughout the CD. This is the way the Beatles wanted \\"Let It Be\\" to be released in the first place -- Gone are the Phil Spector orchestra and choral affects and the interlude pieces -- \\"Maggae Mae\\" and \\"Dig It.\\" Instead, an outstanding uptempo version of \\"Don't Let Me Down\\" has been added. The studio banter heard on the original \\"Let It Be\\" LP has also been eliminated, except for John Lennon's famous: \\"I hope we passed the audition\\" at the end of the CD.   Make no mistake about it, the original \\"Let It Be\\" is a classic.  Considering what was happening with the Beatles and Apple LTD at the time, Phil Spector did the best he could with what he had to work with -- raw tapes and little, if any,  guidance or direction from any of the Beatles.  John worked closest to Spector.  But, once again, keep in mind that in the 1970's the Beatles were more busy recording solo efforts and making court appearances to settle questions about tax liabilities, management, and other business matters that they, initially, did not have to worry about -- thanks to Brian Epstein.      I do not believe that this is Sir Paul McCartney's attempt to rewrite the Beatles' Legacy. Ringo Starr and George Harrison (to a degree) agreed on this project. Yoko Ono also agreed with this project. As a matter of fact, Ringo Starr give this release a powerful endorsement prior to its release. McCartney may have a big ego. But, that is not the case with this recording. This is, simply, releasing \\"Let It Be\\" the way the Beatles had intended it to be released in the first place.   I agree with a lot of other reviewers in that some of the studio banter should have remained on the disc and perhaps the full-blown version of \\"Dig It\\" would have been a welcomed addition -- considering that the recording industry is no longer hampered by keeping recorded music to under 45 minutes (like it was during the heyday of the 33-1/3 LP). Personally, I would have preferred the \\"Red Apple\\" Label on the CD along with the original cover of the \\"Get Back\\" / \\"Let It Be\\" LP. As you recall, prior to the familiar LP cover to \\"Let It Be,\\" the original cover concept was similar to the \\"Red\\" and \\"Blue\\" Beatles Collection LPs that were released after the Beatles disbanded. I believe that this would have made a better cover than the \\"film roll.\\"   Overall, in my opinion, this is a good CD that die-hard and casual Beatles fans can appreciate. And, Yes, the band has passed the audition. . . . . Again!
B0000CDLA7|3.0|I have read many of the reviews on the newest DT release TOT.<BR>I believe it is not worthy of the praise that some are giving it and equally this CD does not deserve some of the harsh criticism it has received. On the upside this CD as compared to current mainstream music is a gem. I was impressed with Labrie's vocal performance. I believe the Vocals to be one of the strongest parts of this release. Portnoys drumming is respectable along with Myungs and Jordans performance, the only problem is I can't find much in this CD that is different or more special than their previous performances. Blade Runner truly deserves to be in a class with all the scifi classics.

0060012358|5.0|A friend gave me this book for my birthday, explaining that it was a book about rats.  Was I ever surprised when I opened the cover and started reading.  It is not just about rats.<br />Pratchett has done his work.  I believe him when he says that he read loads about rats before beginning this.  But not only the rat part is accurate.  When he describes rat writing (pictograms, could be hieroglyphic-like), it parallels the history of the development of human writing.  The rats in this story provide a kind of microcosm of how human society might have developed; their dreams of utopia do not come from out of the blue.  The rats have their version of a holy book, a keeper of the flame, and of course their characters are all very different and sometimes conflict.  Baseness, greed, and corruption all figure in the story, and the rats need to discover how to deal with this new threat called EVIL (as the book's back cover will also tell you).  <br />Although the mentally-mutated (smart) rats naturally figure prominently in the story along with a mentally-mutated cat (Maurice), I think that it also works as an allegory.  You can read this story either for face value or more deeply.  In the latter way, I think that Terry Pratchett critiques current society.  It's funny that reading about rats would make one question humanity, but that's what happened to me!  <br />In a way this book is about having dreams and trying to fulfill them, and getting disillusioned along the way but not giving up.  However, it has no morality overtones and despite its seriousness, it is also pretty funny (take the tap-dancing rat named Sardines, for instance).  The story ends on a happy note too but it isn't overly saccharine.  In a way, it's like pop philosophy and a good story rolled into one.  <br />I was also able to read this story without knowing anything at all about Discworld.
B0000T6JH4|1.0|Yes...I can understand McCartney's complaints that Phil Spector's overproduction on the original &quot;Let It Be&quot; album destroyed The Beatles' intentions with the project. But, I admit, when I first heard of &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; I had said, &quot;This I've gotta hear!&quot;, expecting something along the lines of a reproduction of the original, ill-fated &quot;Get Back&quot; album, some excerpts of which were released on &quot;Anthology 3&quot;. However, I was quite surprised when I purchased &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; and found it quite literally being the original &quot;Let It Be&quot; album -albeit in a different track order, and adding &quot;Don't Let Me Down&quot; (the original B-side of &quot;Get Back&quot;)- minus Phil Spector's additions. Yes, the orchestral arrangements were a little bit overbearing, but the offhand &quot;Dig It&quot; jam as well as the between song patter (&quot;'I dig a pygmy'...&quot;) is gone as well. Yes, the sound is clearer, but that's 2003 technology compared to 1969 is all. In a nutshell, I already own &quot;Let It Be&quot;! Now it's like I have two copies of the same album...and the addtional &quot;Fly On The Wall&quot; CD is nothing but a twenty one minute teaser. All in all, &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; is a bit of a ripoff, and I doubt I was the only Beatles fan who more or less felt cheated by it. Clearly Apple Corps is milking The Beatles name and their catalog for all its worth (but what else is new? Look at the umpteen million old Capitol compilations!). It all leaves me wondering if, considering Michael Jackson owns The Beatles' catalog, if he knew he'd be having legal troubles, and needed the extra cash all the royalties from &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; would give him. In hindsight, there's nothing wrong with the 1970 original (sorry, Paul)...obviously Spector had a good reason to make his additions; the performances weren't exactly of normal Beatles' caliber to begin with...&quot;Across The Universe&quot; and &quot;The Long And Winding Road&quot; admittedly needed the extra work. Without the overdubs, they just sound tired and unperfected. &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; is a disappointment.

B0000T6JH4|1.0|As if switching &quot;Lennon/McCartney&quot; to &quot;McCartney/Lennon&quot; wasn't bad enough (of an insult to John Lennon's memory) on the &quot;Back In The USA&quot; album, now we have literally a reissue of what most people consider The Beatles' weakest album to begin with, made altogether weaker by wimpy sound (the guitars are buried in the mix, and all the rooftop ambience of &quot;I've Got A Feeling&quot; and &quot;One After 909&quot; is GONE.) So, who cares if &quot;The Long And Winding Road&quot; was smothered in orchestration? One, it needed it (according to many Beatles books, including Lewisohn's &quot;Recording Sessions&quot;, John Lennon made so many mistakes on the bass it had to be covered up!) and, besides, people have heard the song like that for 33 years already. Heck, the whole album...no, &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; is simply more of Paul McCartney trying to singlehandedly take credit for The Beatles' accomplishments. He's nothing as a solo artist anymore, so all Sir Paul can do is go on, &quot;Hi, remember me!!!I'm a former Beatle!&quot; He's worse than Jagger or Bowie or any of those guys for living off of his past (at least they manage to pull of something new that's actually good once in a while!.) I doubt very highly, if Lennon or Harrison were still around, this revamped &quot;Let It Be&quot; would exist (after all, L &amp; H were the ones who commissioned Phil Spector to make something out of the original in the first place!) Yes, good or bad, McCartney more or less made the whole &quot;Let It Be/Get Back&quot; project happen back in 1969. But two versions of the same album are not necessary. A better idea (what I was expecting, truth be told) would have been to issue the original &quot;Get Back&quot; album with the original Glyn Johns mixes in the original sleeve design (what became the front cover of &quot;1967-1970&quot; (Blue Album)) All &quot;Let It Be...Naked&quot; is is more of McCartney's ego-stroking...and I doubt very highly that he needs the money.
B000002ARV|5.0|Johnny Winter's &quot;comeback&quot; album from 1973.  Johnny is one of the most underrated guitar players that ever picked up a 6-string.  While deeply rooted in the blues, Johnny delivers some rippin' stripped-down rock and roll on this album.  Production is held to a very minimum of overdubs, and it's basically Johnny with his bass player and drummer.  No effects, no slick production tricks, just good old rock and roll.  He's one of those rare guys that can just plug the guitar into and amp and rip it up.   In addition to his masterful playing, Johnny serves up some of his patented gritty, soulful vocals.<br />I have worn out two copies of this album, and one or two 8-track copies.  This is the fourth time I have bought this, and it's just as fresh as it was in 1973.  <br />If you like simple straight forward rock and roll from a master guitarist, this is a mandatory album for your collection.

B0000BWVCM|5.0|I waited for three years for &quot;X2&quot; to be released, and I walked into the theater saying to myself, &quot;Please God, don't let this movie suck like Batman and Robin&quot;.  I walked out of it a happy person, as Bryan Singer continues the X-Men saga in high fashion.<br />&quot;X2&quot; is an improvement over its predecessor in almost every single way.  It is longer and the charatcers are given more screen time.  The action is better (the military attack on the X-school is probably the film's action highlight).  The script is tighter and more focused, and the film is overall much more ambitious.<br />Singer took some obvious risks with &quot;X2&quot;.  Its themes are very dark for a mainstream comic book movie- genocide, parental rejection, repressed trauma.  Magneto continues to be a great villain- not evil, but horribly misguided.  Forcing him and the X-Men into an uneasy alliance was probably Singer's best move.  The theme of the X-Men's curse is made more obvious here- they are doomed to protect people who hate and fear them.  However, beneath all the darkness, this film is still fun- there's a couple moments of comic relief, and Wolverine still exudes a playful charm.  Singer manages to strike the right balance here between welcome in-jokes and downright campiness, such as what the &quot;Batman&quot; franchise fell into.<br />To make things even better, &quot;X2&quot; is fully loaded with special features, including commentary and several making-of documentaries.  I would highly recommend this film not only for X-Men fans, but fans of good action films in general.  It's much better than most of the other stuff released this year, a welcome relief from the disappointments of &quot;Daredevil&quot;, &quot;The Matrix&quot; sequels, and &quot;Terminator 3&quot;.  I simply love this movie.

B00009TB5G|4.0|I'm a huge &quot;Lord of the Rings&quot; geek.  I've seen both films countless times and I've read the books twice.  Though it was an excellent movie, I was somewhat upset with the theatrical cut of &quot;The Two Towers&quot; for not following the book.  That is somewhat remedied in the Special Edition, which has some nice extras.<br />There is between 30 and 45 minutes of added footage (I've heard various numbers and I didn't bother to time it), and for the most part I loved it.  There are some scenes that add nothing to the film and probably should have stayed cut from the film- a nightime conversation between Aragorn and Gandalf and a final goodbye between Faramir and Frodo are the most glaring examples.<br />However, the character of Faramir is finally given some justice in the Special Edition, as he's shown as a more complex and conflicted character (unfortunately, it still takes him a while to let Frodo and Sam go).  I also loved the added footage of Merry and Pippin with Treebeard- look for references to the cut Tom Bombadil scene from &quot;Fellowship&quot;.  Overall, the characters are better fleshed out, and their interaction with one another is far more interesting than it had been in the theatrical cut.<br />I'd definitely recommend the Special Edition to fans of the book.  It overall feels much more like a Tolkien product than the theatrical cut, and adds some scenes that they would have liked to have seen in the original cut.  However, the more casual fans of &quot;Lord of the Rings&quot; who only like the action may want to stick with the theatrical cut- the Special Edition has a lot more talking than fighting.  Me being a book fan, I absolutely loved this version.

0451167716|5.0|Recently, I've read The Godfather again and I quite couldn't stop  reading! Read this novel is a great pleasure. <br />I think some people don't regard it as great literature because this work doesn't have: flowers, metaphors and blablabla's that most people admire in classic books. In my humble opinion, this is such a great story that doesn't have space for these things (and don't need them). This is a book written in a very simple style.<br />However, as I said, Mario Puzo had in mind a great tale. The Godfather, for me, is the story of Michael Corleone, the kid son of Don Corleone (the kingpin of the Mafia in New York). This story show us how we cannot control our lives, how our families, our honor, and the enviroment around us, makes us what we are!<br />Michael Corleone is the wisest son of Don Corleone but he doesn't want to become a Mafia Don as his father! Different of his brothers he decides to be out of his \\"family's business\\". He wants to become a typical american citizen. He goes to fight in the second world war, goes to college, dates an american woman, and he doesn't take his father's advices. He is the toughest and independent of his brothers.<br />But in one day everything changes for Michael. In the day that his father is shot and he goes to see him in the hospital!!! When he gets a punch from a police captain that is being paid to help killing Don Corleone, Michael sees that he cannot avoid entering in his family's business anymore. Then his destiny is traced and he no longer can live the life he has been planning.<br />Beyond the Michael tale, the lives of all the other characters in this book are well explored and detailed. This is the point where the movies are not very good, for me. In the movies we don't have access to the thoughts and motivations of the main characters, we don't see how wise some of them are, which is one of the greatest pleasures in the book.<br />The blood thirsty of Sonny Corleone and his mafia war is not well explored inthe movies (we just see some newspapers!!). The Johny Fontane character. The story of Conny Corleone, the daughter of Don Corleone, etc. There are a lot of details that aren't and couldn't be covered in the movie.<br />For the fans of great stories I strongly recommend this book.

There's also a strange motel clerk with secrets of his own.<br />But this is not a usual &quot;whodunit&quot;.  No way. B000002HH9|3.0|When I bought this album, and listened to it, I found myself a little confused about what it was trying to say and why it just didn't sound like the dark-edgy cure we were used to listen years before with Disintegration and Co. There are some unusual tunes in this CD, like the caribbean inspired &quot;The13th&quot;, or the wacky &quot;Gone!&quot; that make you wonder what Smith was going through when he wrote them. I must admit that this album didn't hold me mesmerized at first, and I even thought some of its songs, like &quot;club america&quot; were kindda bad. However, after a closer inspect, I started to understand the territory the band was exploring here, and very thought-inducing songs like &quot;this is a lie&quot;, &quot;bare&quot; or &quot;jupiter crash&quot; kept drilling in my ears and resounded in my mind for weeks.<BR>At first look, Wild Mood Swings might sound a little too happy or even uninspired for your goth taste. Songs like &quot;mint car&quot; or &quot;round&amp;round&amp;round&quot; might appear a little too soft and superficial at first, but once you start to understand the space that the album dives into, you realize that the band is trying to communicate a wicked point of view about being grown and finding some reward after such a prosperous-but-always-gloomy career. <BR>With Wild Mood Swings, the band tries to express what they understand as happyness, but like the cracked clown in the cover of the CD, they hopelessly render themselves unable to fullfill their own wish to be happy as their songs keep having the ever crying and opportune happy-but-nostalgic lyrics by the unique Robert Smith. <BR>Despite a few songs, I find this CD highly recommendable, as it explores an always obscure side of The cure: A need to be happy and rest.<br />The Cure are forever sad mimmes singing in the dark. No matter how happy their songs might sound like, they always end up communicating a very melacolic and sad view of their own reality. And that is no a bad thing.

B0000DI86O|5.0|Until recently (November 2003) the only DVD edition of Andrea Chenier was a 1975 film version with Franco Corelli in the title role.  This one is much better.  It is an excellent live production filmed at Covent Garden in 1985.  It illustrates why the Royal Opera is one of the world's leading companies.<br />The three principals -- Placido Domingo as Chenier, Anna Tomowa-Sintow as Maddalena de Coigny, and Giorgio Zancanaro as Carlo Gerard -- are all in the prime of their careers at the time of this filming, and handle their roles superbly.  They are backed up by a solid group of supporting singers.  The orchestra does justice to Giordano's rich score without ever drowning out the singers.  The sets and costumes are appropriate and never distracting.  In short, this is exactly what one would expect to see in a first-rate production at a first-rate opera house.

B00006AG5N|5.0|There is no entertainer more famous than Elvis Presley, consider that this man split the history of modern music in two. The underground vibrations of blues, the popular form of country and the classic sense of gospel all came into a revolutionary clash and mingle embodied by Elvis. Without Elvis you don't get The Beatles, Jim Morrison, Aerosmith, Bono, Marilyn Manson or anything called rock n' roll, he embodied what the word was and what the music meant. It is only fitting that The King of Rock N' Roll get a collection polished to have a sound quality better than even the latest U2 release. &quot;30 #1 Hits&quot; pulses, grinds and croons with songs that are forever famous, some have become so deeply etched into the psyche of the world that it is hard sometimes to understand how Elvis changed the world of music. His face and mannerisms have already been converted into the stuff of worldwide parody or the decor of a postage stamp, but that is only testament to the impact of the man who is known by first name alone. This album contains his #1 hits, some are classics we all hear at some point or another in our lives like &quot;Hound Dog,&quot; &quot;Heartbreak Hotel&quot; or &quot;It's Now Or Never.&quot; The difference is here they have been lovingly polished to a gloss, the sound quality is extremely impressive, never sounding low or dated. Nobody can deny that this is the best-sounding Elvis collection ever released. It is on par with the sound quality of a newly released album. And of course, the music is great. &quot;Can't Help Falling In Love&quot; has to be one of the greatest of all ballads, a wonderfully dreamy expression. &quot;You're The Devil In Disguise&quot; is pure rock n' roll fun with a catchy chorus and memorable production. &quot;Suspicious Minds&quot; remains one of Elvis' best cuts, it's catchy, and good pop fare, but it's also deep and moving with exquisite production. Some of the tracks have reportedly been remixed from the originals, is it a problem? Of course not if you appreciate good music, nothing here feels weak or tampered with. Bettered, yes, ruined, no. Few singers can have such a memorable voice like that of Elvis Presley, his is a deep baritone, rich and full and filled with driven talent. Traces of the vocal influence can be found everywhere from The Doors' &quot;The Crystal Ship&quot; to U2's &quot;With Or Without You.&quot; &quot;30 #1 Hits&quot; is a great collection of the 20th century's biggest singer, it has been compared to &quot;The Beatles 1&quot; but let's remember, without the material here, that album wouldn't be around.

B000031WD9|5.0|I like to review the film by itself and then the DVD...<br />Film - No one avoided this film like me. From what I had seen and heard about the film, it seemed that the writer and director took themselves way too seriously for a typical sex-filled teen comedy. Luckily, this film is not typical. The writing is crisp and the jokes are very funny. The characters reflect real teens (although they are all well-spoken and extremely pretty). The teen boys are neither jerks nor big softies (with the exception of Chris Klein's character). The girls are not naive, but also not entirely jaded. The acting is solid. 0780020685|5.0|Akira Kurosawa (1910-1998) is probably one of the best directors of all time. His 1954 film entitled &quot;Seven Samurai&quot; (&quot;Shichinin no samurai&quot; in transliterated Japanese) is regarded as one of his best films and is without a doubt one of the best films ever made.  The film is about a small farming village in sixteenth or seventeenth-century Japan that is under threat of repeated attacks from a band of 40 bandits.  Being unable to afford weapons of their own and having little spirit to defend themselves, the villagers seek guidance from their elder, Gisaku (Kokuten Kodo, 1887-1960), who advises them to find several ronin (wandering samurai) to defend the village and who would be willing to work for three square meals per day since that is all the villagers can afford to pay.  Several villagers travel to a nearby city to find willing ronin.  They include Manzo (Kamatari Fujiwara, 1905-1985), Yohei (Bokuzen Hidari, 1894-1971), Mosuke (Yoshio Kosugi, 1903-1968) and Rikichi (Yoshio Tsuchiya).  The first ronin that they find is Kambei Shimada (Takashi Shimura, 1905-1982), who is accompanied by a young man wanting to become a samurai, Katsushiro Okamoto (Isao Kimura, 1923-1981).  Kambei is not interested at first, but changes his mind when he sees the villagers' desperation.  Kambei and Katsushiro are able to find four more samurai:  the humorous Gorobei Katayama (Yoshio Inaba, 1921-1998), the no-nonsense &amp; highly skilled Kyuzo (Seiji Miyaguchi, 1913-1985), Heihachi Hayashida (Minoru Chiaki, 1917-1999) and Shichiroji (Daisuke Kat, 1910-1975).  Then, there's also the very humorous, samurai-want-to-be named Kikuchiyo (played the world-renowned actor Toshir Mifune, 1920-1997).   The seven travel back to the village and begin preparations for the coming battle with the bandits, but some of the villagers are afraid of what will happen to their daughters with seven samurai roaming around; especially Manzo, who forces his daughter Shino (Keiko Tsushima)to disguise herself as a boy.<br />Though &quot;Seven Samurai&quot; is approximately 206 minutes (nearly 3 hours) long, it never becomes tiresome.  Instead, the film is very engaging, emotional and powerful as the story develops in large part due to superb acting, exquisite cinematography and the overall realism of the film.  The acting skills of both Takashi Shimura and Toshir Mifune stand out brilliantly. Toshir Mifune, who made many other excellent historically based Japanese films, also appeared in many western films including the character of Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto in the 1976 World War II epic &quot;Midway&quot; and the character of Lord Toranaga in the 1980 TV-miniseries adaptation of James Clavell's novel entitled &quot;Shogun&quot;. Memorable scenes in &quot;Seven Samurai&quot; include Kambei disguising himself as a priest, Kambei's technique of testing each samurai's reactionary skills, the battle between Kyuzo and the foolish samurai, Manzo disguising Shino, Kikuchiyo's drunkenness, the walk to the village with Kikuchiyo, the arrival at the village, Kambei studying the terrain, Kikuchiyo instructing villagers, the battle scenes and the graveyard scenes.  Other memorable characters in the film include Rikichi's wife (Yukiko Shimazaki) and the bandit chief (Shinpei Takagi, 1902-1967).<br />Overall, I rate Akira Kurosawa's cinematic masterpiece &quot;Seven Samurai&quot; with a resounding 5 of out of 5 stars.  It often brings tears to my eyes each time that I watch the film.  I highly recommend the DVD version of the film to everyone.  Sadly, the DVD is only available in full screen, but that does not detract from Akira Kurosawa's grand vision. &quot;Seven Samurai&quot; was remade in 1960 as the epic western &quot;The Magnificent Seven&quot;, which starred Yul Bryner, Steve McQueen and Charles Bronson portraying gunfighters instead of samurai.

B000007MVM|5.0|This is a great solo album period. After Syd left/was fired from the Floyd in the late 60's most of the public was hungry for a second helping of the top 40 hits he released from the band and also from the their excellent psychedelic hit album &quot;The Piper at the Gates of Dawn&quot;. Well soon as Syd gathered what was left of his feeble sanity he released this to surprisingly little success and welcome. It was mostly an underground hit, but the Pink Floyd were doing no better with their &quot;soul searching&quot; albums such as &quot;Ummagumma&quot; and &quot;Saucerful of Secrets&quot;. To be perfectly blunt, most of Pink Floyd(especially Waters)were intimdated by Syd's creative genius(and they do admit it), fearing that his solo works would far outdo their albums as a band. However, Roger Waters and David Gilmour both produced this record, but to listen to it you would never guess it. The sound is brittle and thin, much in contrast to the Floyd's elegant, symphonic sound they often produced. This works out great for the album though, giving it a more mellow, intimate touch that Syd possessed himself. The songs are mostly just Syd with his guitar occassionaly backed up by the Soft Machine to add a litte meat to the over all sound. &quot;Terrapin&quot; is a great opener, a dreamy, almost lazy sounding song concering relationships of love among sea animals. This cut and &quot;Golden Hair&quot; are both the creap of the crop. The latter is Syd performing a poem written by one of his favorite poets James Joyce. Most cite &quot;Dark Globe&quot; as another great track but I cannot listen to it without sadness. The song is like listening to a man croon out his mental illness to the world. Listening as he breaks apart, losing sanity; I skip it most of the time. Other than that this is a great album, but if your expecting something sounding like the Floyd be warned this is Barrett not Pink Floyd and yes their is a rather big difference. This is the Madcap masterpiece!
B0000DD7LB|5.0|I was always a fan of Britney's older material (Baby One More Time, Oops I Did It Again, Slave), but wasn't surprised to see her switch to a more young adult audience with this album. All the songs are pretty good though some are annoying. <BR>1.) Me Against The Music - the first single off the album - a good dance song 4/5<BR>2.) Me Against The Music Rishi Rich Remix - As the title says, it's a remixed version of Me Against The Music (track 1). It's got a very funky beat to it. Once again, very good at a dance club. 4/5<br />Over all, this is a great addition to the Britney line of albums. Our Britney is growing up!

B00008DDSC|4.0|The Secretary alternately shocks and surprises us with its unusual subject matter and intense approach to its off-beat subject.  Maggie Gyllenhaal plays Lee Holloway, a young girl just released from a mental institution who is determined to get a job.  She notices a sign posted outside a lawyer's office for a secretary.  As she enters the office she watches the former holder of this job leaving in tears.  She then introduces herself to Mr. Grey, the lawyer, ably played by James Spader.  Mr. Grey's office is the first clue that something unusual is in store for her.  Rare flowers are beautifully showcased in an exotic setting.  Additionally, the lawyer appears to have a fetish for neatness.  He quickly removes from sight a row of carefully arranged markers.<br />Lee gets the job and begins her initiation into a new world of strange and bizarre behavior.  Lee has a habit of punishing herself for real and imagined faults.  We watch her in the bathroom of her home cutting herself.  She has scars all over her body from past abuse.  She soon begins to cut herself in the office and is noticed by her boss.  At first he says nothing, but when she makes a variety of errors on the reports she is assigned to type, he yells at her and then takes sterner measures.  He tells her to come into his office and then demands that she lean over his desk and place her palms on the desk surface.  She complies and is spanked by the the lawyer.  She submits to this indignity and even seems to like it.  Lawyer and secretary enter into a relationship which allows each to satisfy their deep need to hurt and be hurt.<br />The secretary falls in love with her boss and tells him so.  He is unable to respond to her affections and fires her.  Like Bartelby the Scrivener, she prefers not to be fired and visits him at his home and then takes up residence in the office.  She comes to the attention of the media who publicize her unusual actions. The relationship between lawyer and secretary improves and deepens when he observes her commitment to him.  The climax of the film is both unexpected and original, as is the entire movie.<br />For those new to the sado/masochistic world, this film is disturbing, yet fascinating.  What motivates these people to act as they do?  The movie does not answer this perplexing question.  Instead, it allows us to draw our own conclusions as we watch each new development in the story.  For those willing to suspend the first inclination to judge the lawyer and secretary as just plain crazy, a deepening understanding of the variety of human experience reveals itself.  We observe the various ways these people respond to the pain they suffer in their lives.<br />The limited spectrum of what we believe to be normal behavior is stretched considerably with each new development of the story.  I was reminded of The Piano Teacher, a much better film on this subject of sado/masochism that I reviewed some months ago.  The Secretary is not up to the high standard of The Piano Teacher, but still worth recommending.deepens when he observes her commitment to him.  The climax of the film is both unexpected and original, as is the entire movie.<br />For those new to the sado/masochistic world, this film is disturbing, yet fascinating.  What motivates these people to act as they do?  The movie does not answer this perplexing question.  Instead, it allows us to draw our own conclusions as we watch each new development in the story.  For those willing to suspend the first inclination to judge the lawyer and secretary as just plain crazy, a deepening understanding of the variety of human experience reveals itself.  We observe the various ways these people respond to the pain they suffer in their lives.<br />The limited spectrum of what we believe to be normal behavior is stretched considerably with each new development of the story.  I was reminded of The Piano Teacher, a much better film on this subject of sado/masochism that I reviewed some months ago.  The Secretary is not up to the high standard of The Piano Teacher, but still worth recommending.

0316666343|1.0|If you want to read a poorly organized book with stock characters, and dangling story lines, then this is the book for you!  <br />I had the opportunity to read this book with my book club, and we all agreed it was poorly written. You could point out an endless list of impossibilities like this - and yes I understand that itis just the author's interpretation of heaven.  It's just I really think you need people and situations to develop and grow as a human being, not just &quot;fluffy&quot; heaven that is like high school , and presents no opportunities for personal growth.<br />It was a very frustrating read overall, and I am desperately trying to get rid of my copy!  Save your money for another book!
